recipes.name: Lemon-Turmeric Chicken and Rice with Pickled Red Onion

ingredients.item: scallions, white and green parts separated and sliced thin
jalapeño chile, stemmed and sliced into thin rings

instructions: Whisk ¼ cup lemon juice, sugar, and ½ teaspoon salt together in medium bowl; add onion and toss to combine. Whisk yogurt, lemon zest, and ⅛ teaspoon salt together in small bowl. Refrigerate onion mixture and yogurt separately until ready to serve.

Combine 1½ teaspoons salt, turmeric, ginger, cinnamon, and pepper in second small bowl. Pat chicken dry with paper towels and sprinkle all over with spice mixture. Heat oil in 12-inch skillet over medium-high heat until just smoking. Add chicken skinned side down and cook without moving until well browned, 4 to 5 minutes (do not flip chicken; only 1 side is browned). Transfer chicken browned side up to clean plate; set aside.

Off heat, stir scallion whites and garlic into fat remaining in skillet and cook in residual heat until fragrant, about 1 minute. Stir in broth, rice, remaining 2 tablespoons lemon juice, and remaining ½ teaspoon salt, scraping up any browned bits.

Nestle chicken into rice mixture, browned side up, along with any accumulated juices. Bring mixture to simmer over medium-high heat, then reduce heat to low. Cover skillet and simmer until liquid is absorbed and chicken registers at least 175 degrees, 18 to 20 minutes. Remove skillet from heat and let rest, covered, for 5 minutes.
Drain onion and discard remaining liquid. Dollop yogurt mixture over chicken and rice in skillet. Sprinkle with pickled onion, jalapeño, and scallion greens. Serve.

recipes.name: Cuban-Style Roast Pork Shoulder with Mojo

ingredients.item: boneless pork shoulder roast, rind removed

instructions: In a small bowl, combine minced garlic, cumin, black pepper, oregano, and 1 tablespoon salt to form a paste. In another bowl, whisk together orange juice, lime juice, and olive oil until well combined.

Using a sharp knife, make 1-inch-deep slits all over the pork shoulder. Rub the garlic spice paste into the slits and all over the surface of the meat. Pour the citrus-oil mixture over the pork, massaging it into the meat.
Place pork in a large roasting pan or dish, cover with plastic wrap, and refrigerate overnight (or at least 4 hours) to marinate.
Remove pork from refrigerator 1 hour before cooking. Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Remove plastic wrap and pour ½ cup water around (not over) the pork in the roasting pan.
Roast the pork, basting every 30 minutes with pan juices, until the internal temperature reaches 155°F (68°C) and the exterior is well-browned and crispy, about 2-3 hours total.
Remove pork from oven and transfer to a cutting board. Cover loosely with foil and let rest for 20 minutes.

Pour the cooking juices from the pan into a small saucepan, scraping up any browned bits. Skim off excess fat and simmer the sauce over medium heat. Stir in fresh mint and oregano. Season with salt to taste.
Slice the pork and serve with the mojo sauce drizzled over top. Garnish with lime wedges. Traditionally served with black beans, rice, and fried plantains.

recipes.name: Big and Bubbly Focaccia

ingredients.item: flaky sea salt (like Cyprus or Maldon)

instructions: In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, salt, sugar, and yeast. Add the water and 1 tablespoon olive oil and stir until the mixture is thoroughly combined and homogeneous; there should be no dry patches or lumps. Cover the bowl and set aside for 15 minutes.

Perform the first bowl fold: Use a wet hand to grab a section of dough from one side of the bowl, then lift it up and press it into the center. Repeat this motion around the bowl 8 to 12 times. Flip the dough over so the smooth side is up. Cover and let rest for 15 minutes.
Repeat the bowl fold process three more times, resting 15 minutes between each fold. The dough should feel smoother and stronger with each fold.
After the fourth fold, cover the bowl and let the dough rise at warm room temperature (70°F to 75°F) for 1 hour, until nearly doubled in size and very puffy.

Spray a 9-inch square pan with nonstick spray. Cut a 3-inch-wide strip of parchment about 16 inches long and lay it across the center of the pan with overhang on two sides. Spray the parchment and add 1 tablespoon olive oil, tilting to spread evenly.

Gently transfer the risen dough to the center of the pan. Using your hands, flip the dough to coat it in oil. Cover and let rise for 1 to 1½ hours, until marshmallowy and jiggly, nearly filling the pan.
Preheat oven to 475°F with racks in upper and lower thirds. Oil your fingers and dimple the dough thoroughly, pressing to the bottom of the pan, spacing dimples about 1½ inches apart.
Drizzle the remaining 1 tablespoon olive oil over the surface and sprinkle evenly with flaky salt.
Bake on the lower rack for 15-18 minutes, until brown in the highest spots and golden in the crevices. If needed, broil briefly for 1-2 minutes for desired color.
Remove from oven, lift out using parchment tabs, remove parchment. Return to oven directly on lower rack for 5-7 minutes until sides are golden and crisp. Cool on a wire rack.
